Glossary

# 

<span key="36900f54e4984fd9af8283b2e2859911"><span offset-key="36900f54e4984fd9af8283b2e2859911:0">Single-page Application</span></span>

<span key="ee90629d28b04b6f994635b01568517c"><span offset-key="ee90629d28b04b6f994635b01568517c:0">A single-page application is an application that loads a single HTML page and all the necessary assets (such as JavaScript and CSS) required for the application to run. Any interactions with the page or subsequent pages do not require a round trip to the server which means the page is not reloaded.</span></span>

<span key="cc7847e34a9e42458d9fc9d0e8e2bfe8"><span offset-key="cc7847e34a9e42458d9fc9d0e8e2bfe8:0">Though you may build a single-page application in React, it is not a requirement. React can also be used for enhancing small parts of existing websites with additional interactivity. Code written in React can coexist peacefully with markup rendered on the server by something like PHP, or with other client-side libraries. In fact, this is exactly how React is being used at Facebook.</span></span>

# 

<span key="a6f8bfed21c84d3db6eea1aa69e2915a"><span offset-key="a6f8bfed21c84d3db6eea1aa69e2915a:0">ES6, ES2015, ES2016, etc</span></span>

<span key="49d6a761af054caeb09ce168c4f37318"><span offset-key="49d6a761af054caeb09ce168c4f37318:0">These acronyms all refer to the most recent versions of the ECMAScript Language Specification standard, which the JavaScript language is an implementation of. The ES6 version (also known as ES2015) includes many additions to the previous versions such as: arrow functions, classes, template literals, </span>`let`<span offset-key="49d6a761af054caeb09ce168c4f37318:2"> and </span>`const`<span offset-key="49d6a761af054caeb09ce168c4f37318:4"> statements. You can learn more about specific versions </span></span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECMAScript#Versions" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c8d7af35d45d41b99da1192b9b9f76af" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="2a8cdfe36aef410996742b33bfbb7642"><span data-offset-key="2a8cdfe36aef410996742b33bfbb7642:0">here</span></span></span></a><span key="feb33abaeafa4ac6bdf5cba582611130"><span offset-key="feb33abaeafa4ac6bdf5cba582611130:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="98a00e5a2c2541978f5c22ad894b4234"><span offset-key="98a00e5a2c2541978f5c22ad894b4234:0">Compilers</span></span>

<span key="52abde8e317f432384392b0fad4cf66d"><span offset-key="52abde8e317f432384392b0fad4cf66d:0">A JavaScript compiler takes JavaScript code, transforms it and returns JavaScript code in a different format. The most common use case is to take ES6 syntax and transform it into syntax that older browsers are capable of interpreting. </span></span><a href="https://babeljs.io" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4afc6b0251d24dc1bfc81bc59b0e5bcc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="a8787d7efd524fb69d053a9264860888"><span data-offset-key="a8787d7efd524fb69d053a9264860888:0">Babel</span></span></span></a><span key="c60d7c17c6d9400881905e42536a70c6"><span offset-key="c60d7c17c6d9400881905e42536a70c6:0"> is the compiler most commonly used with React.</span></span>

# 

<span key="bb7a536f31db4c5aa67863a7088f3966"><span offset-key="bb7a536f31db4c5aa67863a7088f3966:0">Bundlers</span></span>

<span key="78212d02670440f08f13ebe5a47e1e25"><span offset-key="78212d02670440f08f13ebe5a47e1e25:0">Bundlers take JavaScript and CSS code written as separate modules (often hundreds of them), and combine them together into a few files better optimized for the browsers. Some bundlers commonly used in React applications include </span></span><a href="https://webpack.js.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2df32b9235504d33ab503dee32f5e5cb" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="193b3bc2460144ddab5675ad01ba7f40"><span data-offset-key="193b3bc2460144ddab5675ad01ba7f40:0">Webpack</span></span></span></a><span key="c4c1e721215d40dfa4942b57501df601"><span offset-key="c4c1e721215d40dfa4942b57501df601:0"> and </span></span><a href="http://browserify.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d8cb7fe48cba48ec9640eb0f4b157659" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="cf3d98b92224439f8e4014106502fd16"><span data-offset-key="cf3d98b92224439f8e4014106502fd16:0">Browserify</span></span></span></a><span key="751202a211ef41e99392897e24b800d8"><span offset-key="751202a211ef41e99392897e24b800d8:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="00e695ef2feb4664ab5a12fd9be5f916"><span offset-key="00e695ef2feb4664ab5a12fd9be5f916:0">Package Managers</span></span>

<span key="353778bd987f4a21b3628f2c5241eea8"><span offset-key="353778bd987f4a21b3628f2c5241eea8:0">Package managers are tools that allow you to manage dependencies in your project. </span></span><a href="https://www.npmjs.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7fe37c091f8149ca9558e705e5485d42" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="6f4c8135a53648be9d5bbd303d1c4295"><span data-offset-key="6f4c8135a53648be9d5bbd303d1c4295:0">npm</span></span></span></a><span key="2094b2dedf30471aae28c03448868ad9"><span offset-key="2094b2dedf30471aae28c03448868ad9:0"> and </span></span><a href="https://yarnpkg.com" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="caa472f7f85d485f8ea81a1daa8742e2" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="0c18e964307e43a583a4cdf682b088dd"><span data-offset-key="0c18e964307e43a583a4cdf682b088dd:0">Yarn</span></span></span></a><span key="17a400ed61fe43c1b7d4c7a473dc6a34"><span offset-key="17a400ed61fe43c1b7d4c7a473dc6a34:0"> are two package managers commonly used in React applications. Both of them are clients for the same npm package registry.</span></span>

# 

<span key="f6f3cc383ded4e7ca695c9279d45d437"><span offset-key="f6f3cc383ded4e7ca695c9279d45d437:0">CDN</span></span>

<span key="a352e4588c3e48739e13fbe98a41a3d9"><span offset-key="a352e4588c3e48739e13fbe98a41a3d9:0">CDN stands for Content Delivery Network. CDNs deliver cached, static content from a network of servers across the globe.</span></span>

# 

<span key="31bda860fc3644f18665f2afb8b111f2"><span offset-key="31bda860fc3644f18665f2afb8b111f2:0">JSX</span></span>

<span key="90d511b1901c4cc2ab54b400336258f9"><span offset-key="90d511b1901c4cc2ab54b400336258f9:0">JSX is a syntax extension to JavaScript. It is similar to a template language, but it has full power of JavaScript. JSX gets compiled to </span>`React.createElement()`<span offset-key="90d511b1901c4cc2ab54b400336258f9:2"> calls which return plain JavaScript objects called “React elements”. To get a basic introduction to JSX </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/introducing-jsx.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4fb1d1e5820b4f99a724982e9b7abedb" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="52984a272aab43ed986154d6e0aa4658"><span data-offset-key="52984a272aab43ed986154d6e0aa4658:0">see the docs here</span></span></span></a><span key="cce27e69f01c4751ace6bd8bde80fb80"><span offset-key="cce27e69f01c4751ace6bd8bde80fb80:0"> and find a more in-depth tutorial on JSX </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/jsx-in-depth.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="9a3a9a0a3d9d48a49677c9a72375feee" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="06d6d8cc6d8646e194a9cc7e6948b442"><span data-offset-key="06d6d8cc6d8646e194a9cc7e6948b442:0">here</span></span></span></a><span key="d4756baef4b9477a8a1a6fc6dc68501a"><span offset-key="d4756baef4b9477a8a1a6fc6dc68501a:0">.</span></span>

<span key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94"><span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:0">React DOM uses camelCase property naming convention instead of HTML attribute names. For example, </span>`tabindex`<span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:2"> becomes </span>`tabIndex`<span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:4"> in JSX. The attribute </span>`class`<span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:6"> is also written as </span>`className`<span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:8"> since </span>`class`<span offset-key="f59813f5f0924abaa8ed44a3c17c1a94:10"> is a reserved word in JavaScript:</span></span>

1

<span key="de609e93657947918edafec7216f46fb"><span offset-key="de609e93657947918edafec7216f46fb:0">const name = 'Clementine';</span></span>

2

<span key="efba1d7a4dc843e6ae978861baca37eb"><span offset-key="efba1d7a4dc843e6ae978861baca37eb:0">ReactDOM.render(</span></span>

3

<span key="3898518d3de144a0a97699971d6dc7ea"><span offset-key="3898518d3de144a0a97699971d6dc7ea:0"> &lt;h1 className="hello">My name is {name}!&lt;/h1>,</span></span>

4

<span key="be8e79c8ca7a41e183089ad7b370d9bd"><span offset-key="be8e79c8ca7a41e183089ad7b370d9bd:0"> document.getElementById('root')</span></span>

5

<span key="1bdc6ee1e9964f1d8b05f636960f5d45"><span offset-key="1bdc6ee1e9964f1d8b05f636960f5d45:0">);</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="85d53c76778e4413b882ac13dd6ffa73"><span offset-key="85d53c76778e4413b882ac13dd6ffa73:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/rendering-elements.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a358d96c18f24bc1a3d6f5f5cd8f7aba" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="6acdf942c7894cdab30ca18848d09b29"><span data-offset-key="6acdf942c7894cdab30ca18848d09b29:0">Elements</span></span></span></a><span key="d5416df0978945509490767ffd671993"><span offset-key="d5416df0978945509490767ffd671993:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="8129ea8abfa04de8ac779d6a573f6238"><span offset-key="8129ea8abfa04de8ac779d6a573f6238:0">React elements are the building blocks of React applications. One might confuse elements with a more widely known concept of “components”. An element describes what you want to see on the screen. React elements are immutable.</span></span>

1

<span key="87baacd78ba24d97afd45f01e2cfa0f0"><span offset-key="87baacd78ba24d97afd45f01e2cfa0f0:0">const element = &lt;h1>Hello, world&lt;/h1>;</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ca5ff3eb2de8488c9a0c804655a7cc2e"><span offset-key="ca5ff3eb2de8488c9a0c804655a7cc2e:0">Typically, elements are not used directly, but get returned from components.</span></span>

# 

<span key="c031aec440644764963e544dab95974f"><span offset-key="c031aec440644764963e544dab95974f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/components-and-props.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="338b464d41ed41c3a0da96b4c4a994ba" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="6615376e5a514e0a9779c5ceb257363b"><span data-offset-key="6615376e5a514e0a9779c5ceb257363b:0">Components</span></span></span></a><span key="18ee4568c71341209a2961d8a92439ef"><span offset-key="18ee4568c71341209a2961d8a92439ef:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="d4ef4b4fb9754fbc9fe1b730036b0ec2"><span offset-key="d4ef4b4fb9754fbc9fe1b730036b0ec2:0">React components are small, reusable pieces of code that return a React element to be rendered to the page. The simplest version of React component is a plain JavaScript function that returns a React element:</span></span>

1

<span key="640cce3b25924db3a39f288835e0ac4d"><span offset-key="640cce3b25924db3a39f288835e0ac4d:0">function Welcome(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="c8795c6ce1df4cb7b011ee6620f109cf"><span offset-key="c8795c6ce1df4cb7b011ee6620f109cf:0"> return &lt;h1>Hello, {props.name}&lt;/h1>;</span></span>

3

<span key="6761f64fa28343a6877909e57bdc1fec"><span offset-key="6761f64fa28343a6877909e57bdc1fec:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b326a58527454cc7a607a4588d272aac"><span offset-key="b326a58527454cc7a607a4588d272aac:0">Components can also be ES6 classes:</span></span>

1

<span key="53baa9cd2c5043efb4757736227b2816"><span offset-key="53baa9cd2c5043efb4757736227b2816:0">class Welcome extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="ffa07f116b4e4e45be8fa54458e33f57"><span offset-key="ffa07f116b4e4e45be8fa54458e33f57:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="a8dea7f7ba3c406583d05fdf098c38c3"><span offset-key="a8dea7f7ba3c406583d05fdf098c38c3:0"> return &lt;h1>Hello, {this.props.name}&lt;/h1>;</span></span>

4

<span key="2e3a6f929e4242d5a6fe5e4a9b20cb2a"><span offset-key="2e3a6f929e4242d5a6fe5e4a9b20cb2a:0"> }</span></span>

5

<span key="f9be31d89104415ab367b50157f37708"><span offset-key="f9be31d89104415ab367b50157f37708:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="32b16d21b9564fc9b4751be34dc3c9a6"><span offset-key="32b16d21b9564fc9b4751be34dc3c9a6:0">Components can be broken down into distinct pieces of functionality and used within other components. Components can return other components, arrays, strings and numbers. A good rule of thumb is that if a part of your UI is used several times (Button, Panel, Avatar), or is complex enough on its own (App, FeedStory, Comment), it is a good candidate to be a reusable component. Component names should also always start with a capital letter (</span>`<Wrapper/>`<span offset-key="32b16d21b9564fc9b4751be34dc3c9a6:2"> </span>**not**<span offset-key="32b16d21b9564fc9b4751be34dc3c9a6:4"> </span>`<wrapper/>`<span offset-key="32b16d21b9564fc9b4751be34dc3c9a6:6">). See </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/components-and-props.html#rendering-a-component" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="debb492ff0fb4cc494ece3523ecb6674" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="dcb580151f8e4d49b53fff56347da6f4"><span data-offset-key="dcb580151f8e4d49b53fff56347da6f4:0">this documentation</span></span></span></a><span key="28ff08ebadee407fafb7d58d5105b964"><span offset-key="28ff08ebadee407fafb7d58d5105b964:0"> for more information on rendering components.</span></span>

## 

<span key="cea66b4d9a074423883cac45758dbd5a"><span offset-key="cea66b4d9a074423883cac45758dbd5a:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/components-and-props.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="2adb07c4b9074a24a0e9509ff982aa35" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="7eb34abe9add46b9bea55046169d579c"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="7eb34abe9add46b9bea55046169d579c:0">props</code></span></span></a><span key="631f6dc9fa994907848ef74d79501b98"><span offset-key="631f6dc9fa994907848ef74d79501b98:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="800dba00f4514e42a4239d3d4544f798">`props`<span offset-key="800dba00f4514e42a4239d3d4544f798:1"> are inputs to a React component. They are data passed down from a parent component to a child component.</span></span>

<span key="caadc670004f43acb72484831b156973"><span offset-key="caadc670004f43acb72484831b156973:0">Remember that </span>`props`<span offset-key="caadc670004f43acb72484831b156973:2"> are readonly. They should not be modified in any way:</span></span>

<span key="36d9bec875d2457c95c8ae42d8b6fc4c"><span offset-key="36d9bec875d2457c95c8ae42d8b6fc4c:0">If you need to modify some value in response to user input or a network response, use </span>`state`<span offset-key="36d9bec875d2457c95c8ae42d8b6fc4c:2"> instead.</span></span>

## 

<span key="85cc2b33f1944a95b007527a6312f888">`props.children`</span>

<span key="fdb858c1e7294910a2ee0fc2448d114e">`props.children`<span offset-key="fdb858c1e7294910a2ee0fc2448d114e:1"> is available on every component. It contains the content between the opening and closing tags of a component. For example:</span></span>

1

<span key="3bacc63a01e641348ac7325e873b2e2b"><span offset-key="3bacc63a01e641348ac7325e873b2e2b:0">&lt;Welcome>Hello world!&lt;/Welcome></span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e1b22e1307b3453399b256a3257789a2"><span offset-key="e1b22e1307b3453399b256a3257789a2:0">The string </span>`Hello world!`<span offset-key="e1b22e1307b3453399b256a3257789a2:2"> is available in </span>`props.children`<span offset-key="e1b22e1307b3453399b256a3257789a2:4"> in the </span>`Welcome`<span offset-key="e1b22e1307b3453399b256a3257789a2:6"> component:</span></span>

1

<span key="c6173eae28de4ef6bd5a08ce53a17c83"><span offset-key="c6173eae28de4ef6bd5a08ce53a17c83:0">function Welcome(props) {</span></span>

2

<span key="8b249473d9d44f53b8782ec39ed2996c"><span offset-key="8b249473d9d44f53b8782ec39ed2996c:0"> return &lt;p>{props.children}&lt;/p>;</span></span>

3

<span key="5a8a12148bf64ea59ea4a596239b4329"><span offset-key="5a8a12148bf64ea59ea4a596239b4329:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ebd5b6347f9a413fb1fce9cbadd2dc5c"><span offset-key="ebd5b6347f9a413fb1fce9cbadd2dc5c:0">For components defined as classes, use </span>`this.props.children`<span offset-key="ebd5b6347f9a413fb1fce9cbadd2dc5c:2">:</span></span>

1

<span key="28030454ee3b4e03bdedc7499dfa16c7"><span offset-key="28030454ee3b4e03bdedc7499dfa16c7:0">class Welcome extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="b093548ed9794987bfe6fe2a55e8a8fb"><span offset-key="b093548ed9794987bfe6fe2a55e8a8fb:0"> render() {</span></span>

3

<span key="1e7c80646ea24f73a4ae9217f6210fe0"><span offset-key="1e7c80646ea24f73a4ae9217f6210fe0:0"> return &lt;p>{this.props.children}&lt;/p>;</span></span>

4

<span key="f43a5e4840084ed8ae5bb5bc9630555f"><span offset-key="f43a5e4840084ed8ae5bb5bc9630555f:0"> }</span></span>

5

<span key="54c13f7270e54f06883a205eb1dc4a94"><span offset-key="54c13f7270e54f06883a205eb1dc4a94:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="06219a7bffd74830a877719ea4f007ed"><span offset-key="06219a7bffd74830a877719ea4f007ed:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/state-and-lifecycle.html#adding-local-state-to-a-class" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="d7800f257fc04c8395936343def77b1b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="192c1cd8065446eeb58e46c5f1715446"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="192c1cd8065446eeb58e46c5f1715446:0">state</code></span></span></a><span key="9dc45acc900f44ac8496c94a52474d19"><span offset-key="9dc45acc900f44ac8496c94a52474d19:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917"><span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:0">A component needs </span>`state`<span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:2"> when some data associated with it changes over time. For example, a </span>`Checkbox`<span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:4"> component might need </span>`isChecked`<span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:6"> in its state, and a </span>`NewsFeed`<span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:8"> component might want to keep track of </span>`fetchedPosts`<span offset-key="effe498106b14d4f8c8a03dfb0879917:10"> in its state.</span></span>

<span key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c"><span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:0">The most important difference between </span>`state`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:2"> and </span>`props`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:4"> is that </span>`props`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:6"> are passed from a parent component, but </span>`state`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:8"> is managed by the component itself. A component cannot change its </span>`props`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:10">, but it can change its </span>`state`<span offset-key="841bde3a529144f4a7907a07fcc4389c:12">.</span></span>

<span key="60eced4bc1b74b0f8445ab65855290c7"><span offset-key="60eced4bc1b74b0f8445ab65855290c7:0">For each particular piece of changing data, there should be just one component that “owns” it in its state. Don’t try to synchronize states of two different components. Instead, </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/lifting-state-up.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="30a6aad409f34b20baff872ef7f409ed" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="475c541fda1643d5b4e3cfab3d768f5a"><span data-offset-key="475c541fda1643d5b4e3cfab3d768f5a:0">lift it up</span></span></span></a><span key="a6311b8e294e4247bdf48f9952c6516f"><span offset-key="a6311b8e294e4247bdf48f9952c6516f:0"> to their closest shared ancestor, and pass it down as props to both of them.</span></span>

# 

<span key="c68ef7ce929d43f8afab358d55f9d9bc"><span offset-key="c68ef7ce929d43f8afab358d55f9d9bc:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/state-and-lifecycle.html#adding-lifecycle-methods-to-a-class" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="cee54fa1d972442daf5ac0054815ac25" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="ef88e3e3bdc94ec1b9b2d244dc1ce150"><span data-offset-key="ef88e3e3bdc94ec1b9b2d244dc1ce150:0">Lifecycle Methods</span></span></span></a><span key="30ff45a6dc934472bf27e55561b2afd8"><span offset-key="30ff45a6dc934472bf27e55561b2afd8:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="893c62ea183047cf9ae0c257f6767716"><span offset-key="893c62ea183047cf9ae0c257f6767716:0">Lifecycle methods are custom functionality that gets executed during the different phases of a component. There are methods available when the component gets created and inserted into the DOM (</span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/react-component.html#mounting" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6719082146fb4c829b48a8879b652adf" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="70547d59efac4ef1993689828f964653"><span data-offset-key="70547d59efac4ef1993689828f964653:0">mounting</span></span></span></a><span key="dc2ccd29f6834a60b75443d9cef61e83"><span offset-key="dc2ccd29f6834a60b75443d9cef61e83:0">), when the component updates, and when the component gets unmounted or removed from the DOM.</span></span>

# 

<span key="7ef27ae66732407bbaf08a81109c71f3"><span offset-key="7ef27ae66732407bbaf08a81109c71f3:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/forms.html#controlled-components" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3d9b3294eb5243649c58be35c87b8dab" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="318731b21014497aa61ccc0d36d33c59"><span data-offset-key="318731b21014497aa61ccc0d36d33c59:0">Controlled</span></span></span></a><span key="5a2bd9e561a64bbd93a8b5f3f2d7427c"><span offset-key="5a2bd9e561a64bbd93a8b5f3f2d7427c:0"> vs. </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/uncontrolled-components.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="71b3a55c781540d7a1d6c4dc8a82358c" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="4458833fbe4b4d2d9c125fc54b1b21c8"><span data-offset-key="4458833fbe4b4d2d9c125fc54b1b21c8:0">Uncontrolled Components</span></span></span></a><span key="6cf3e99500af48d691674dee24e9d27c"><span offset-key="6cf3e99500af48d691674dee24e9d27c:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="5e80d6a056ce47d99bbd79683fccea09"><span offset-key="5e80d6a056ce47d99bbd79683fccea09:0">React has two different approaches to dealing with form inputs.</span></span>

<span key="042ec6ad888b42b394d87414982b17df"><span offset-key="042ec6ad888b42b394d87414982b17df:0">An input form element whose value is controlled by React is called a </span>*controlled component*<span offset-key="042ec6ad888b42b394d87414982b17df:2">. When a user enters data into a controlled component a change event handler is triggered and your code decides whether the input is valid (by re-rendering with the updated value). If you do not re-render then the form element will remain unchanged.</span></span>

<span key="e151ac0eabea431aa0f041b19f2c455c"><span offset-key="e151ac0eabea431aa0f041b19f2c455c:0">An </span>*uncontrolled component*<span offset-key="e151ac0eabea431aa0f041b19f2c455c:2"> works like form elements do outside of React. When a user inputs data into a form field (an input box, dropdown, etc) the updated information is reflected without React needing to do anything. However, this also means that you can’t force the field to have a certain value.</span></span>

<span key="45afa0a9b35b4f45ab84a654bb936924"><span offset-key="45afa0a9b35b4f45ab84a654bb936924:0">In most cases you should use controlled components.</span></span>

# 

<span key="171b13ce04bc4148b1b6539ce6e305a1"><span offset-key="171b13ce04bc4148b1b6539ce6e305a1:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/lists-and-keys.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e239608bb48f496c9322f76aaed36f28" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="45869506def443f785ca7c0c81b5cadc"><span data-offset-key="45869506def443f785ca7c0c81b5cadc:0">Keys</span></span></span></a><span key="20fb2a8d925a4defa024739478b51a86"><span offset-key="20fb2a8d925a4defa024739478b51a86:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="fb9db0ddfa5d41e6981644b02ea7107a"><span offset-key="fb9db0ddfa5d41e6981644b02ea7107a:0">A “key” is a special string attribute you need to include when creating arrays of elements. Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or are removed. Keys should be given to the elements inside an array to give the elements a stable identity.</span></span>

<span key="420734a403d4489abb41e666ac637013"><span offset-key="420734a403d4489abb41e666ac637013:0">Keys only need to be unique among sibling elements in the same array. They don’t need to be unique across the whole application or even a single component.</span></span>

<span key="834add98d8744d63971960fdd60664fe"><span offset-key="834add98d8744d63971960fdd60664fe:0">Don’t pass something like </span>`Math.random()`<span offset-key="834add98d8744d63971960fdd60664fe:2"> to keys. It is important that keys have a “stable identity” across re-renders so that React can determine when items are added, removed, or re-ordered. Ideally, keys should correspond to unique and stable identifiers coming from your data, such as </span>`post.id`<span offset-key="834add98d8744d63971960fdd60664fe:4">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="eb86601876bd4f77845c8d37e24800fa"><span offset-key="eb86601876bd4f77845c8d37e24800fa:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/refs-and-the-dom.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6f1bf993380140bfa37e305524515110" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="7701b50f4eab4b62a1aaffbeb7a4c19b"><span data-offset-key="7701b50f4eab4b62a1aaffbeb7a4c19b:0">Refs</span></span></span></a><span key="ec0896eb200d4545983c6f5d21062fda"><span offset-key="ec0896eb200d4545983c6f5d21062fda:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="65dccadfc6fd4ff492a1db89ba2c87c1"><span offset-key="65dccadfc6fd4ff492a1db89ba2c87c1:0">React supports a special attribute that you can attach to any component. The </span>`ref`<span offset-key="65dccadfc6fd4ff492a1db89ba2c87c1:2"> attribute can be an object created by </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/react-api.html#reactcreateref" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="c5c2b3dac613427aba399963a304d246" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="5b9a1a9d3b2748f789ce4dfce16ff98e"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="5b9a1a9d3b2748f789ce4dfce16ff98e:0">React.createRef()</code><span data-offset-key="5b9a1a9d3b2748f789ce4dfce16ff98e:1"> function</span></span></span></a><span key="b3681c13078441bea58a3eba733e2051"><span offset-key="b3681c13078441bea58a3eba733e2051:0"> or a callback function, or a string (in legacy API). When the </span>`ref`<span offset-key="b3681c13078441bea58a3eba733e2051:2"> attribute is a callback function, the function receives the underlying DOM element or class instance (depending on the type of element) as its argument. This allows you to have direct access to the DOM element or component instance.</span></span>

<span key="c2eeffa33b774e7f8822ff950fdd7225"><span offset-key="c2eeffa33b774e7f8822ff950fdd7225:0">Use refs sparingly. If you find yourself often using refs to “make things happen” in your app, consider getting more familiar with </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/lifting-state-up.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4a422089cf8447a8be30f658df275a27" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="0504a55d8fab450daa8fe209945b2e7c"><span data-offset-key="0504a55d8fab450daa8fe209945b2e7c:0">top-down data flow</span></span></span></a><span key="4e84a5e2f9634cdf8a178611f24cdfc6"><span offset-key="4e84a5e2f9634cdf8a178611f24cdfc6:0">.</span></span>

# 

<span key="2c03de6d1aa64931b5b2c2c79bf88b5c"><span offset-key="2c03de6d1aa64931b5b2c2c79bf88b5c:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/handling-events.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="843562d44aab49b2a7dec3fe57d8221e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="884dd542f0214c67967a6993fa176103"><span data-offset-key="884dd542f0214c67967a6993fa176103:0">Events</span></span></span></a><span key="0ffc9743c02148818de4f518209f6cee"><span offset-key="0ffc9743c02148818de4f518209f6cee:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="a1910abc94c84427b9cf8a6e66d92f4e"><span offset-key="a1910abc94c84427b9cf8a6e66d92f4e:0">Handling events with React elements has some syntactic differences:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4cc8a31eebdc43ab9a56e4ee1f92c1ef"><span offset-key="4cc8a31eebdc43ab9a56e4ee1f92c1ef:0">React event handlers are named using camelCase, rather than lowercase.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="48a93ff615fb45b7a6b24ba2e8515d26"><span offset-key="48a93ff615fb45b7a6b24ba2e8515d26:0">With JSX you pass a function as the event handler, rather than a string.</span></span>

# 

<span key="da2f2887e6ab48c68999df7f7c418a9b"><span offset-key="da2f2887e6ab48c68999df7f7c418a9b:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/reconciliation.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="cb1f8743299d4f4b82289ed1580907cd" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-68757_259-68758-237__"><span data-key="18d40c740e56459995ded2e3fb36ff76"><span data-offset-key="18d40c740e56459995ded2e3fb36ff76:0">Reconciliation</span></span></span></a><span key="2bb103905bcc48ff99a73fa38895d67e"><span offset-key="2bb103905bcc48ff99a73fa38895d67e:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">​</span></span></span>

<span key="8ad1502c2c454505ae426977959ae3fb"><span offset-key="8ad1502c2c454505ae426977959ae3fb:0">When a component’s props or state change, React decides whether an actual DOM update is necessary by comparing the newly returned element with the previously rendered one. When they are not equal, React will update the DOM. This process is called “reconciliation”.</span></span>

<a href="objects.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1awozwy r-14lw9ot r-190qawg r-z2wwpe r-rs99b7 r-4dj0k7 r-1loqt21 r-1quu1zo r-1ro0kt6 r-18u37iz r-16y2uox r-1wbh5a2 r-nsbfu8 r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"></a>
